thread.title: Kampua mee, Sitiawan-style

author: NOEL FOO
title: Kampua mee, Sitiawan-style
text:
by noel foo The Clear Soup Lou Shu Fan can be considered as comfort food and the pork balls served with it are quite tasty. 
THOSE who love kampua mee are likely to think of Sibu as the home of this noodle dish, but the Sitiawan version is very much worth a try too. 
You can find this lesser-known version of the traditional Foochow or Hock Chew dry noodle dish at the five-month-old restaurant, Mian (Noodles), at Sunwaymas Commercial Centre, Petaling Jaya. 
Mian is founded by married couple Ting Guo Yi, 26, and Jacy Chua, 30, who run the restaurant together with their friend Wong Yian Yian, 37. 
Wong handles the marketing aspect of the business. 
The idea for the restaurant came from Ting, who decided to serve modified versions of the original black kampua mee recipe, a speciality at his uncle’s shop in Sitiawan, Perak. 
Chua, who is an interior designer by profession, shares her husband’s love for food and she’s the person behind the restaurant’s modern and minimalist interior design. The more tasty Black Kampua Noodles (bottom) pairs quite well with the Village Chicken (top) while the peanut-flavoured White Kampua Noodles (middle left) complements the homemade Char Siew (middle right). 
Ting says kampua noodles are typically handmade, and due to its starchy nature, the noodles absorb sauces easily and must be eaten quickly before it gets too soggy. 
At Mian, kampua mee , which translates as “dry plate noodles” in the Hock Chew dialect, is served in two forms: black and white. 
The black kampua mee is closer to the original Sitiawan recipe. It is made with soy sauce, pork and lard, and served with fried onion garnish, crunchy bean sprouts and clear wantan soup. 
The savoury taste of soy sauce pairs very well with the plainer village chicken. Ting recommends adding a little of their homemade pickled garlic and vinegar sauce to give a slightly sharp tinge to the flavour. 
The white kampua mee is made with a homemade peanut oil sauce, instead of soy sauce. If you have peanut allergies, then stay clear. 
Mildly flavoured, it has minced pork in place of bean sprouts, and is best paired with Mian’s sweet homemade char siew (barbecued pork). Mian, a restaurant that specialises in Sitiawan-style Hock Chew Kampua Noodles, opened in Sunwaymas Commercial Centre, Petaling Jaya about five months ago. 
Explaining why their char siew is black in colour instead of red, Ting says this is because the meat does not contain red food colouring. Moreover, they use more caramelised black sauce to get a better taste. 
While kampua mee is the highlight at Mian, there are a few other noodle dishes worth trying too, including the prawn mee hoon . 
The dish comes with rather generous helpings of ingredients – two prawns, a whole hard-boiled egg, siew yuk (roasted pork), bean sprouts and other vegetables. But what really sets it apart is the broth. 
Made from a combination of prawn stock and pork broth, it is concentrated and gives the dish a very rich prawn flavour. 
Another item on the menu is the clear soup lou shu fan . 
The recipe for this comfort food comes from Chua’s grandmother. Coffee lovers may be delighted to know that Mian serves Vietnamese Drip Coffee for just RM5. 
The soup is boiled with preserved vegetables and served with lou shu fan (“rat tail noodles” in Chinese), delicious pork balls, dumplings, beancurd skin ( foo zhuk ) and minced pork. 
The two types of kampua noodles at Mian are served with clear wantan soup and priced at RM6.90 and RM7.50, depending on portion. 
Ordering the dish with char siew or village chicken adds RM1 to the price tag. 
Both the Prawn Mee Hoon and Clear Soup Lou Shu Fan are priced at RM7.90 (regular) and RM8.50 (large). 
Meat items such as village chicken (RM15 for a quarter chicken), char siew (RM5) and siew yuk (RM6) can also be ordered à la carte as side dishes. 
MIAN, No 9-1, Jalan PJU 1/3C, Sunwaymas Commercial Centre, Petaling Jaya. (Tel: 016-692 8147). Business hours: 10.30am to 4.00pm from Tuesdays to Fridays, 9.30am to 4.00pm on weekends, closed on Mondays. Non-halal. 
This is the writer’s personal observation and is not an endorsement by StarMetro.
